bibl.title: Letter from A.S. von Mansfelde to Howard A. Kelly, November 6, 1907

div1.p: Von Mansfelde requests a copy of the program for the Carroll Memorial Dinner and a copy of the letter von Mansfelde wrote Kelly regarding Carroll's promotion. Von Mansfelde adds that he is continuing to work for pensions for the widows of Lazear and Carroll.

div1.head: Letter from A.S. von Mansfelde to Howard A. Kelly, November 6, 1907
div1.opener:
Nebraska State Medical Association
A. S. v. Mansfelde, M. D., Treasurer
“Quality Hill,” Ashland, Nebraska
Dr L
No. 2713
November 6th 1907.
H.A. Kelly M D.
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Doctor Kelly:
div1.p:
Of course, you remember,
how very much I was interested in Dr J.
Carroll and his promotion to the Majority.
He got the commission, but, poor fellow,
he never wore the majors uniform!

I am in receipt of letters from his widow,
and from my young friend, D. H. H Donnally,
Washington, telling me of the memorial at
Baltimore. May I ask you, if printed copies
of these exercises are issued, to remember
me with one? And another request: If you
still possess the first letter I wrote you from
the Cosmos Club, Washington, either December
9th or 10th 1906, will you please have a copy
made of it and send it to me? I will be
very much obliged to you for it, as it is the
only writing from me, or too me, concerning
my dead friend, of which I have no copy,
and I very much desire to complete the chain

2D of 3
Nebraska State Medical Association
A. S. v. Mansfelde, M. D., Treasurer
“Quality Hill,” Ashland, Nebraska
No..........................
of my small indeavors for poor Carroll.

Besides I have been already appointed a
chairman of a committee in The National
Legislative Council a.m a. to prepare a bill
for a special pension for the widow of Dr
Jesse W. Lazear, and I expect to do the same
for my dead friend and his family, Carroll.
My congressman, Hon. Edmund H. Hinshaw,
has already promised, not only to introduce these
bills, but to do his very best for their passage.

Besides I have the promise, extended to
me voluntarily, of the most influential commer-
cial body in America; to second to their best
my endeavor for pensions (special) for these two
families, not less than Dr Reeds widow is
receiving; and I feel that with the initiative
taken by the American Medical Association and
the help of an aroused conscience of indebted-
ness to these heroes by our nation, we will
surely succeed. Please, let me hear from
you.
